review.description:
We did go there on Sunday mid morning , the wait was 1 1/2 hour,but we did not mind the wait , as we went to the local bar ...
The time arrived and we were sited at the bar next to the waitress station so we did had the chance to see how  the work the orders , as well we witness the process of how they prepare the food ...
Four cooks at the grill were in constant movement .....it was a great show to watch.
We ordered the one patty burger and the duck ....
All was delicious .... we eat it all ., service was prompt and friendly ..... 
Ambiance was cozy and hip  , kind of place that you like to stay .... and music was coming of the old fashioned  tape player , the one from 80s, brings the old memories .....
Great food great place ....... hope to be back ....
review.author: Leszek J.

review.description:
Great prices for gourmet burgers!

Came here later at night & enjoyed fried eggs over our bacon cheeseburgers as well as our fries. 

Sauces available are on point & the pickle on the side made it a perfect cap to a whole day of exploring Chicago. A little dark inside & loud music offsets the ambiance but somehow you don't hear any of it from outside.
review.author: Roger D.

review.description:
I'll keep commentary on these burgers short, because I'm sure you don't need any convincing. They are delicious. Simply crafted- cooked to perfection and carefully dressed with a creamy sauce and pickles. If you don't get the burger at Au Cheval, you're not doing it right. 

The fries have perfect texture- crispy while maintaining the integrity of a soft potatoey inside. They're served with garlic aoli. The tang and creaminess of the sauce marries so well with that classic french fry flavor and crunch. 

If you're looking to lighten up you meal, I would highly recommend the green salad. It was simple- lettuce served with a pickled shallot, herb, and sherry vinagrette. A refreshing contrast to the heaviness of the other menu items. If it comes down to salad or fries, I think I'd even go with the salad because it was that good. 

We arrived around 5 on a Friday night and had a short 30-45 minute wait. Well worth it!
review.author: Olivia L.

review.description:
This iconic Chicago burger joint has been on our to-do list for a long time. Finally that box is checked! Navigating the wait to get in is the tricky part but we managed to finagle a 90 minute wait vs a more typical 2-3 hour stint with some strategic planning in this small space. 

The cocktails are really good here, which helps the wait time. Their burgers are pretty spectacular. The single has 2 perfectly cooked juicy patties, American cheese, pickles & their own special sauce served on maybe the best brioche hamburger bun ever. The meat to bun ratio is perfect however about halfway through I found the sauce to be a tad one note & added a little ketchup, much to the horror of my dining companions. Hey if they didn't want me to use ketchup, why did they put the bottle on the table? We also split a salad, fries, and got the bread & butter pickles. 

Definitely one of the best burgers I've ever eaten & the bun was killer! The service was also great.
review.author: Mac R.

review.description:
A lot of hype leads to high expectations. And they do deliver!! Heard a lot about this place, the double stacked burger as the best you'll ever eat, the long waits, the cool vibe in such a small place. 

Tried to get in on Saturday as the kitchen opened at 5. They don't take reservations so you need to get your name on a list and they'll text you. Told there was a 3 hour wait. Too long for me to wait for any burger. Came back Sunday and was able to order in just under 90 minutes from arrival. Enjoyed some great cocktails as we waited - an unexpected bonus!

Is it the best burger I've ever had? No, but it is certainly near the top. Don't know how they pack so much flavor into that double patty stack on an incredibly tasty bun. But they do. Cooked medium/medium rare it just bursts with flavor. A taste sensation indeed. And that bun alone is worth stopping in for!! Wow. Not worth a 3 hour wait but it certainly is a place you need to try. I'll sure be back.
review.author: Gary R.

review.description:
Wow. I'm not a burger person, but this burger was literally the best I've had in my entire life.

My boyfriend and I came here on a Sunday night and were surprised with a 3 hour wait (they do not take reservations). So we decided to come back Monday for lunch and the wait was only 30 minutes (they actually sent me a text 10 minutes later - yay!). We were seated at the bar and I was fascinated by how the chefs cooked the orders. We ordered a single burger (no cheese) with fried egg (+$2), a double cheeseburger with fried egg (+$2) and thick cut bacon (+$3.50), and crispy fries with mornay sauce, garlic aioli and fried egg. We also got a canned beer and the Flapper cocktail drink. 

Do yourself a favor and don't wear a sweater because this food will fire you up. The single burger actually comes with two thin patties and the double burger comes with three. The patties were cooked medium/medium rare, the way they taste best. The fried eggs were cooked to perfection and bacon was sweet, perfectly crispy and just the right amount of fat. Together, the burger was just the ultimate combo. The burger order doesn't come with any sides except a dill pickle. Don't underestimate this dill pickle though, because after a very tasty yet heavy burger, the acidity in the dill pickle will make you feel a lot better about yourself. The crispy fries were a little too crispy for my liking, but the sauces were delicious! The Flapper is gin, pepper, lemon, honey and fernet - sharp, crisp and refreshing.

There are so many other unique menu items I would love to try if I'm ever back in Chicago.
review.author: Alyssa W.

review.description:
I'd been hearing about this place for months from  many people. So on a trip to Chicago, I trucked over here through the snow on a Sunday night.

To start, be prepared for a insanely long wait anytime you come here. I came on a Sunday afternoon and the line was out the door into the snow, so I came back Sunday evening and "only had to wait 40 minutes". I grabbed a seat at the bar.

Let's get straight to the point, the burger is excellent. I had the single cheeseburger with no runny egg and an order of fries, and it was sick. The biggest standout about the burger is the sauce. It has a powerful taste that reminds me of the sauce used on a big Mac. The end result is a burger that has a fast food taste, but with a gourmet twist. Delicious. 

The restaurant is more like a blue collar diner and there isn't a lot of seating. Once you're in, things moves very quickly, so figure out what you want and order. They also serve drinks here and a bunch of wines. I had a nice glass of red with my burger.

All in all, this place is a must if in Chicago. I can't say it's the best burger I've ever had, but it's top three for sure. Get here!
review.author: Kevin M.

review.description:
Special place to say the least. So good. Not just the food, but also the space, the vibe, the energy, the music, the drinks, the crowd, the decor, the noise level, the ambiance, the service. Also I had no wait which I guess is pretty unusual and adds to the pleasure. The waitress was so great, she was always there to ask if everything was ok and bring whatever. Sorry I can't review the burger because I didn't have room. I ordered a burger but also chopped liver to start and then couldn't pile a burger on top. The chopped liver was so rich and delicious along with buttered toast and a stack of cornichons, which were the perfect foil. It was coarsely chopped, perfectly seasoned and contained some dill, I think. The beverage choice is huge; I had a glass of champagne and a hefeweissbier.

Love the menu. Brendan failed once, with his deli concept, Dillman's. Now at Au Cheval we find matzoh ball soup, chopped liver, omelets and hash browns. Moral of the story -- if you can't bring people to the deli, bring the deli to the people. Save me a seat at the bar, please!
review.author: Jeff J.

review.description:
The best burger I've ever had in my life. 

Small place with a great vibe. Be prepared to wait for a table or go during off-times. I promise you, this burger is worth the wait. 

Double burger patty, soaked in bone marrow, medium rare, with pickles & onion. KNOCK OUT. This thing is so damn flavorful. 

Necessary additions:
- thick bacon, perfectly seasoned and not fatty like a pork belly. This really adds to the final burger taste explosion
- egg on top, get the yoke flowing, pile on the juiciness
review.author: Eric P.

review.description:
Would give this place 3.5 stars. Minus that .5 because of a little mishap with putting our name down.

Bestie and I came met up with a friend of hers here around 5 on a rainy Monday night. He arrived first and put us down for 3. Host said the wait would be 40mins-1hr. Decided to trek a couple blocks to the monster toy door for fun. Came back and waited. After basically waiting an hour and not being called, we checked in at the stand to find out our names weren't even down and never received a confirmation text even though we gave a number. It was upsetting and we were put on the list for real this time and got a confirmation text. Went to Whole Foods and my friends had a drink at the bar. From the confirmation we were able to see how many people were ahead of us, which was nice.It went down pretty fast, we're guessing people dipped out because of the wait. We waited roughly another hour before we were seated. We ordered...

-bone marrow ($17.95): Came with 4 pieces of marrow, bread, and marmalade. This was bestie and her friend's first time trying bone marrow. They weren't impressed but were glad to have tried. I enjoyed it a lot. I really liked the marmalade that it came with.

-single cheese burger($10.95): Best and I split a burger. We added an egg ($1) and the famous bacon ($3.50). Even though it was a single, it came with two patties! The bacon was pretty darn good but adding it on for the price only gave you two small pieces. :(

-fries($5.95) Fries were yum. I kept the marmalade from the bone marrow and dipped my fries in it :3

-smashed potato(5.95): If you like mashed potatoes, Get it, they're good!

Service overall was great! Our server was friendly and attentive. Waters were always topped off. Lighting was very dim inside. With the music it gave off a very lively, but dark feel? Taha.
review.author: Tina N.

review.description:
I'm not going with the masses and agreeing it's the best taste I ever tasted. 

I'm real so I will break down my experience....

The worst bloody marry that has ever touched my taste buds. Over garnished and over salted way to rich not drinkable. It was like drinking the texture of a seed tomatoes milk shake. 

My girl put it aside and I refused to pay for a drink and not get my money's worth. BIG MISTAKE 

So my buds were over salted. 

The fries with the fried egg came out and they cooled down my buds and they were fantastic!!!!

The burgers finally come out......

To me and just me they were out of control Rich. Way too much going on and it felt like a huge bite of salt and maybe my buds were shocked so it was painful. The bacon, patties, cheese and garnishment were to much for me. Every bite was too much for me I was washing them down with water. Every bite was painful and I really tried to love it and talk about how good it tasted. I needed a big gulp of water after every bite. Until I decided I was not enjoying I was tolerating. 

I started to think how manny people agree it's great in conversation. 

Again my experience...
review.author: Luis G.

review.description:
Be prepared for a worth wild wait. Our wait time was approximately two hours, there are plenty of bars on Randolph close by to kill some time. We luckily got a seat at the bar (first come first serve). Sitting at the bar made the experience even better. Sodikoff likes to have an open kitchen setting, so watching these chefs roll out burgers, fries, and other items was incredible. 

I got the cheese burger with fried egg on top, and split the fries and butter & bread pickles with my friend. 

The burger was full of great flavor, not messy at all, delicately placed on the plate. The burger was cooked to perfection. There is a sauce on there almost like a dijonaise sauce that will make your mouth water.  I didn't want to stop eating this burger. The fries were golden brown and the perfect amount of crisp too and had a garlic aioli type of dipping sauce. The bread & butter pickles were a nice side too. 

If you want one of the best burgers in Chicago, be prepared for a great wait for an exciting experience.
review.author: Rebecca J.

review.description:
Wowzers. Alright, let's just start with the hype is real. Yes, you're going to have to wait a bit and maybe even awhile to get a seat, but I gotta say that was one damn good burger!

After two years of living out here and frequent visits to Chicago over the past 5 years, I finally made it out to Au Cheval. Showed up just past 4pm on a Monday afternoon, as I've heard via word of mouth that the work crowd starts to show around 4:30pm and after that you can expect to wait hours on hours. We put in our name for two and the hostess let us know that our table would be ready within the hour and they would text us. Score. We ended up going to  Lone Wolf next door since the bar seating at Au Cheval was completely full. About half way through our first round and we get the text that they're ready for us. 

The restaurant itself isn't that much bigger than a diner. The use of darker woods and low lights on the inside gave it a casual/classy ambiance and I was totally feeling the 80s & 90s throwback jams that they were bumping. Waiter was prompt to bring out menus and a decent selection of craft beers to choose from on tap which I had noticed initially from the lines of taps at the barfront near the entrance. I ended up going with a smuttynose robust porter which was pretty tasty, but filling at the same time. For food, we did an order of general jane's honey-fried chicken w/ chili, sesame seeds, & cilantro. My oh my that was some fried goodness. Sticky, sweet, spicy and perfectly fried chicken. Thank goodness they bring it out with moist towels to wipe yourself after because who uses a knife and fork to eat fried chicken. Not me! 

Of course we did their burgers for the main entree/finale, a single cheeseburger for her and a double cheeseburger for me. Now let me just say here at Au Cheval, a single = two patties and a double = three patties. Had I known this ahead of time, a "single cheeseburger" would've served me well. We both opted for a fried egg and their extra thick cut bacon. By the time I stacked my burger, it could've been mistaken for a quadruple cheeseburger. How'd it taste you say? I've never had a burger with that amount of richness & juiciness and that fried egg and bacon just puts it over the top. In short, BEST BURGER EVER.  

I'll leave it at that. This one is a Chicago rite of passage. 

'Til next time, cheers!

17/365
review.author: Francis R.

review.description:
6 words: It lives up to the hype.

I arrived here around 4pm on a Monday with the intent of beating the after-work crowd. I expected a 1-2 hour wait, but was told I would be seated "within the hour." I put my name in (and phone number, as their waitlist was powered by Nowait), and headed next door for a beer to kill time. Au Cheval has a bar too but it's a relatively small restaurant and the bar was overly crowded.

I barely put my lips on my beer glass when I got a notification that my table was ready! I looked down - barely 15 minutes. Not bad, not bad. I quickly finished my beer and headed back to the restaurant.

We ordered: the chicken wings, a double cheeseburger, and a single cheeseburger. Of course we got eggs and bacon on the burgers.

The wings: The only slightly disappointing thing we tasted. The wings were good, but a little overly sweet. The thing that I wasn't a fan of though? If you're going to charge $17.99 for six chicken wings, they better be DAMN GOOD. These were good, just not anything to brag about.

The burgers. Holy goodness were these things bigger than expected. And rich. the bacon gave the whole thing a sense of umami. The egg - perfect. And the patties? Well, the "single" burger was really composed of two patties, so that was a pleasant surprise. Everything was so good, though heavy.

The drink list: more extensive than I would have thought, and luckily not too up-charged, which was appreciated. You can still grab a craft beer for $6-7, which, considering the location, is quite reasonable.

By no means is this restaurant large, so plan accordingly. Cheers!
review.author: Jean L.

review.description:
MUST TRY BURGERS!!! 

I got the single cheeseburger with bacon and egg added to it. DELICIOUS! The bacon is almost like a millionaires bacon, super thick and sweet. Goes really well with the sunny side egg that melts over the whole burger.

Also got crispy fries with mornay sauce, garlic aioli and fried farm egg. The mornay sauce didn't really taste like anything and the garlic aioli was really flavorful. We also got a side of duck gravy to go along with this. The duck heart gravy is super thick filled with chicken, minced duck heart, sausage and gravy... Sounds exotic but a must try!!
review.author: Jenny S.

review.description:
Not the first time here (or the last) but finally tried ordering something besides just the burger and fries... It's just so hard to say no to one of the best burgers on the planet... 

So went with a group and was able to get a few more things off the menu then usual:

- chicken liver app- creamy, tangy, good... Super rich though, would recommend sharing

- bologna sandwich- so this was a little too salty for me but went over well at the table... made me a little nostalgic for the fried bologna sandwiches my dad used to make me as a kid 

- fries - yep they're good... I actually prefer the plain fries with garlic aioli to the version with mornay/egg but all versions are good... 

- burger- so the star of the show... My favorite version of this is the basic single cheeseburger, nothing added... It's the perfect amount of meat/cheese/sauce/toasted bun that comes together deliciously to be one of the best burgers period... However I do change it up at times- egg when I'm feeling super indulgent (as if the cheeseburger alone isn't enough)... last time it was all in with a double- this was too much for me (shocking I know) but now I can say I've tried the full array of options before deciding on a fav

- dessert - yup there was more ( everything was shared, stop judging) ... Had the Mille feuille (aka Napoleon) and it was good, a nice light ending to the meal

I then walked the mile home in attempt to delay the impending heart attack... Totally worth it
review.author: Tazeen L.

review.description:
So excited to finally try Au Cheval and the famous burger. We got there thinking we would have to wait about hour or so to be seated. But thank god we got seated within 10 minutes. 

We were seated in a booth the scene was nice and actually kinda romantic loved the lighting at the table. Not sure why but I really enjoyed the little light shining in the middle of the table. Waiter came took our order was very nice waiter (forgot to catch his name ) ordered the burger with egg and bacon on top with side of fries. 

Didn't take to long for the food to be served. But when I tried the burger I was bit disappointed. I was expecting a lot more. The pickles and sauce that was on the burger tasted like relish and I hate relish. But the person I was with actually loved the burger. So to each his own, I do have to say this they do have one of the best bacon I've ever had in my life. I love bacon and was very surprised how good it tasted. The fries and dip were also really good. 


I would probably come back and try the burger without the pickles and the sauce that was on it. All in all it was ok for my first time.
review.author: Jesse M.

review.description: Well, the thing about this place is that it's nearly impossible to give it a try. We came here three times and the waiting times are absurd. At 10pm they tell you wait time is five and a half hours - all that means is that you want to create a hype about your restaurant, it's just not realistic. At 2.30pm (they close at 3pm) they say the wait time is two and a half hours. How is that possible if you close in 30min? The question is do you have a table or not?! - They also don't take reservations when you call, but somehow people show up and have a 'reservation'. About the 'best burger in America' I can only say that even their fries with egg is never going to reach 'animal style' - but only in California!
review.author: Philipp P.

review.description:
Many people say this is the best burger in Chicago.
Those people are absolutely correct.
I finally experienced the meaty magic that is the au cheval burger this weekend, and I have to say: it was spectacular. Rich, juicy beef patties, melty cheese, thick cut bacon and a gooey egg... I'm drooling just writing this review! I've never had a better burger.
The fries are quite good too, especially the aioli dipping sauce they come with.
One tip to avoid the wait: try to arrive around 4, you'll be seated by 5:30 and in culinary nirvana by 6.
review.author: Valerie B.

review.description:
Been here 3 times and guess 3rd times a charm to finally write a review of my overall thoughts. Disclaimer: I am not a huge burger fan unless it's a barbecue or I'm feeling like a particular fatty that day.

Known for: burgers (apparently, Bon Appetit cited this as the best burger in America at some point)
Pricing: good, ~$16 (inc. tax +tip)/person for a single burger (+egg) and fries shared b/n 2 people
The wait: even on a weekday, the wait can still get atrociously long, expect 2-3hr wait times for past 5pm on weekends. Was lucky this past Tuesday to only wait 5min @ 5:30pm for 4 people. If you plan on staying around the area, you can put your name and # and they will let you know when your table is ready.

Bone marrow - the marrow itself is good, just small serving (hit and miss) , it's served with an obnoxiously greasy buttered bread (dare I say, too much butter!)
Fries - they just can't get it right - 1 time salty, 1 time stale/lukewarm - I love my aioli, but their's kind of sucks. Aioli too salty and not enough of that garlic taste. Disappointment, but fries always fit in with a burger.
Fois gras terrine - DO NOT ORDER - all 4 of us gave it a thumbs down. We had to convince ourselves to finish it because it would be a waste. I would describe it as head cheese + fois gras = dry pasty thing.

What we really care about: the burgers! 
The standard "single" is prepped with TWO "thin" patties + american cheese + thin homemade pickles + dijonnaise (dijon, mayo, lemon juice).  For the more ferocious eater, you can opt for a double = 3 patties. This is a classic style burger versus the crazy combo 1/2 lb burgers with a gazillion toppings that you may be seeing elsewhere. You can also choose to add: a fried egg, thick cut bacon (more like a pork belly), and fois gras.   

My classic single cheeseburger + fried egg was cooked perfectly. I would probably opt for no egg next time as it did not seem to enhance the flavor much. I wanted to taste more of that american cheese goodness. I really liked the thin pickles and the buns held up nicely to the rich texture of the beef. Meat tasted "fresh" and has that homey yet elevated feel to it. 

Bottom line: go here for burger cravings that you can afford to wait. Not perfect, but it's pretty darn good.
review.author: Nan N.
